data.title: Eniqeq: Projectile Trajectory
data.solution:
#Alternative Solution!
import math

def calculateProjectileTrajectory(theta, v0, x0, y0, g, t):
    # Convert the launch angle from degrees to radians.
    theta_rad = math.radians(theta)

    # Calculate the horizontal and vertical components of the initial velocity.
    v0x = v0 * math.cos(theta_rad)
    v0y = v0 * math.sin(theta_rad)

    # Calculate the horizontal and vertical displacements.
    x = x0 + v0x * t
    y = y0 + v0y * t - 0.5 * g * t**2

    return (x, y)

theta = float(input())
v_0 = float(input())
x_0 = float(input())
y_0 = float(input())
g = float(input())
t = float(input())
x,y = calculateProjectileTrajectory(theta, v_0, x_0, y_0, g, t)


x_rounded = round(x)
y_rounded = round(y)

# Categorize the trajectory
if y_rounded < 0:
    trajectory_category = "near"
else:
    trajectory_category = "far"


print(f"Projectile position at time t = {t}: (x, y) = {x_rounded, y_rounded}")
print(f"trajectory = {trajectory_category}")
data.statement:
Calculate the trajectory of a projectile launched at an angle [[theta]] with an initial velocity [[v0]], neglecting air resistance. Given the initial position {{(x0, y0)}} and the acceleration due to gravity [[g]], determine the position {{(x, y)}} of the projectile at a given time [[t]].

After calculating the trajectory, round the positions to the nearest integer. Then, categorize the trajectory based on the rounded vertical position (y_rounded) into {{near}} which is less than zero, or {{far}} which is zero or above.

Formula:
Horizontal position (x):
x = [[x0]] + [[v0]] * [[t]] * cos([[theta]])
Vertical position (y):
y = [[y0]] + [[v0]] * [[t]] * sin([[theta]]) - 0.5 * [[g]] * [[t]]^2
Degrees to Radians:
radians = degrees * (3.14159 / 180)

testCases.title: Test 1
testCases.testOut:
Projectile position at time t = 2.0: (x, y) = (28, 9)
trajectory = far

data.constraints:
Launch angle: 0 ≤ [[theta]] ≤ 100.
Initial velocity:  0 ≤ [[v0]] ≤ 50.
Initial positions: 0 ≤ [[x0]] ≤ 35  and 0 ≤ [[y0]] ≤ 35.
Acceleration due to gravity: [[g]] = 9.8.
Time: 0 ≤ [[t]] ≤ 10.0.

data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>>: A float [[theta]]: The launch angle of the projectile in degrees.
<<Line 2>>: A float [[v0]]: The initial velocity of the projectile in meters per second.
<<Line 3>>: A float [[x0]]: The initial x-coordinate of the projectile in meters.
<<Line 4>>: A float [[y0]]: The initial y-coordinate of the projectile in meters.
<<Line 5>>: A float [[g]]: The acceleration due to gravity in meters per second squared.
<<Line 6>>: A float [[t]]: The time at which to calculate the projectile's position in seconds.
data.outputDescription:
<<Line 1>>: A string representing the position of the projectile at t:
{{Projectile position at time t = [[t]]: (x, y) = ([[x]], [[y]])}}
After calculating the trajectory, round [[x]] and [[y]] to the nearest integer.

<<Line 2>>: A string representing the category of the trajectory based on the rounded vertical position ([[y]]):
{{trajectory = far}} or {{trajectory = near}}

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Calculate the trajectory of a projectile launched at an angle theta with an initial velocity v0, neglecting air resistance. Given the initial position (x0, y0) and the acceleration due to gravity g, determine the position (x, y) of the projectile at a given time t.

After calculating the trajectory, round the positions to the nearest integer. Then, categorize the trajectory based on the rounded vertical position (y_rounded) into near which is less than zero, or far which is zero or above.

Formula:
Horizontal position (x):
x = x0 + v0 * t * cos(theta)
Vertical position (y):
y = y0 + v0 * t * sin(theta) - 0.5 * g * t^2
Degrees to Radians:
radians = degrees * (3.14159 / 180)
Input
Line 1: A float theta: The launch angle of the projectile in degrees.
Line 2: A float v0: The initial velocity of the projectile in meters per second.
Line 3: A float x0: The initial x-coordinate of the projectile in meters.
Line 4: A float y0: The initial y-coordinate of the projectile in meters.
Line 5: A float g: The acceleration due to gravity in meters per second squared.
Line 6: A float t: The time at which to calculate the projectile's position in seconds.
Output
Line 1: A string representing the position of the projectile at t:
Projectile position at time t = t: (x, y) = (x, y)
After calculating the trajectory, round x and y to the nearest integer.

Line 2: A string representing the category of the trajectory based on the rounded vertical position (y):
trajectory = far or trajectory = near
Constraints
Launch angle: 0 ≤ theta ≤ 100.
Initial velocity: 0 ≤ v0 ≤ 50.
Initial positions: 0 ≤ x0 ≤ 35 and 0 ≤ y0 ≤ 35.
Acceleration due to gravity: g = 9.8.
Time: 0 ≤ t ≤ 10.0.
Example
Input
45.0
20.0
0.0
0.0
9.8
2.0
Output
Projectile position at time t = 2.0: (x, y) = (28, 9)
trajectory = far
